okay basically ARP really performs the function of translating or mapping IP addresses to the Mac or lower level
ethern addresses it's more or less the protocol layer addresses an R header is 28 bytes and obviously when you map that
on top of uh an Ethernet um the ethernet actual header which is 66 and two bytes
it's a pretty small packet there's six General ARP messages there's AR request implies uh reverse request implies and
inverse request and replies they all do different types of mappings between IP addresses and the Mac addresses we're
really going to focus today on the r request and replies
okay now the general basic ARP request message is uh is fairly simple all it
does is it contains the source IP address of the system requesting the uh information um the systems Mac address
or ethernet address it contains the destination IP address and then the broadcast Mac address okay so basically
when a system say wants to Ping another system it builds a ping packet it travels down through the stack when it
actually tries to go out onto the ethernet wire it does a lookup in its ARP cache if it has an ARP entry in
there already or a Mac entry in there already it'll just take that plug it in send the packet on its way if it doesn't
have an Ethernet address it basically builds a r request message sends it out to the system across the wire uh each
ethernet uh Nick will actually look at the packet going by if it's a broadcast it it'll ignore it unless it's its own
um IP address if it's its own IP address it'll basically pick it up uh generate an RP Supply
message and send it back to the destination system at that point the system will basically build up and cache
the IP address and the MAC address and then send the packets on its way so it's very simple uh Stupid it happens all the
time without anybody thinking about it now the key problem here is that
there's no authentication whatsoever with ar messages okay any system anywhere in the network if they can see
our traffic can spoof replies to it now there's a big problem is if you spoof a
reply from one system to another and there is already an entry in the system it's going to overwrite it okay because
it basically takes the newest SHP entry first um if there is not an entry in the system most system will will just
actually add that entry blindly into their cash okay uh it's been called um R
poison cash corruption uh arpel there's all sorts of different names for

stupid picture obviously if you a Hub Network you will basically see all the traffic all the unicast broadcast and

in switch Networks you're going to see the broadcast and multicast uh traffic and you're only going to see traffic destined for you okay so just unicast

address the and destination Mac addresses okay with respect to actually
compromising a switch Network what you need to do the attacker needs to do is basically fool the switch and the

you and then the poor system actually has to pick up the packets and forward on to the
destination now here's a quick example uh if client is talking to the server
basically again the client will generate an AR request broadcast across the wire the server will pick it up and generate
an R reply now the uh hostile system will also see that AR request going across the wire as
well what it's going to do is it's going to generate its own R uh response to
that packet so it's going to basically put the server's IP address into the packet its own Mac address into
the packet and send it back to the client and it'll also probably do the same thing to the server so the client
May receive the uh the server rply first and it's going to cach it but then it's also going to receive the Hostile rply
